awd_abstract_narration:
Recent results around the 'sum-product' and 'product-phenomena' in various fields, rings and groups lead to progress on an amazing number of issues, ranging from computer science to representation theory. The purpose of the proposal is to explore further several types of questions that underlie these applications, in particular the 'product-phenomena' in matrix spaces and the 'expanding properties' of algebraic functions on finite fields.
 
The problems in the proposal are mainly continuing a line of research (in particular by the PI) that turned out to have rather unexpected applications besides their intrinsic interest from the combinatorial point of view. Indeed, purely combinatorial (and basically elementary) techniques brought progress on issues that had stalled for quite some time, such as on the expander properties of certain 'thin' SL2 Caley graphs, and the 'expanding properties' of algebraic functions on finite fields.

por.por_cntn:
The research area of the PI lies at the interface of number theory, combinatorics and their applications to theoretical computer science. The interaction between these fields has been particularly active and fruitful over recent decades with lots of cross fertilization. Samples of breakthroughs are the polynomial time primality testing, the construction of deterministic randomness extractors and advances in the theory of expander graphs. In all these cases, progress came by combining insights from different fields and analytical boundaries were moved under the impetus of `new' questions that `standard ' results just felt short of answering.
The PI's research belongs to this general direction and what follows is an illustration of this in non-technical language as much as possible. A first item is the problem of finding quadratic non-residues (QNR) in a finite field or in a residue ring (mod q). How small is the least such quadratic non-residue? On one hand, this is a famous problem in number theory with many partial contributions, some of them conditional to the generalized Riemann hypothesis. On the other hand, finding a QNR is a basic step in various algorithms in computer science, from where the desirability of being able to locate a QNR in a very short interval (as this reduces the search time). Despite many decades of research there is still a large gap between conjectured and proven results. The PI's work on character sums over short intervals for composite moduli has the merit of unifying certain methods and providing the strongest results to date when the modulus q has small prime factors (in particular when q isa so-called smooth number). In this situation, QNR's may be found in intervals as short as any small power of the modulus and the results obtained make this statement even more precise. On the mathematical side, there is a pleasing application to primes in arithmetic progressions: for large modulus q  (Linnik's problem): If q has sufficiently small prime factors and b is any integer coprime with q, there is a prime p<q^c such that p=b  (mod q). Here c is a constant that roughly can be taken as small as 2.4 (while in general, only c=5.2 is known so far).
When it comes to derandomization and devising  deterministic algorithm, the common agreement is that, without access to `true randomness', structures of algebraic nature sometimes offer a good substitute. This is the field of `pseudo-randomness' which is a topic of intensive research by different groups of mathematicians.
One central theme here is that of `unlikely intersections'. A typical example of a relevant phenomenon is that, very crudely speaking, the intersection between an object with additive structure and one with multiplicative structure is likely going to be small (this is what underlies lots of recent developments in arithmetic combinatorics around sum-product theory). Partly in joint work, the PI obtained new results on the intersection of various polynomial images of intervals in finite fields. A very recent application in applied sciences involves new polynomial time probabilistic algorithms to reconstruct a polynomial from a small number of samplings. In pure math, the results lead to progress on polynomial iteration in finite fields and the size of orbits of points. The latter may in some sense be viewed as a dynamical counterpart of the classical Artin conjecture on multiplicative orders, another well-known open problem in number theory.
